title: Dental Caduceus Pendant
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Made as a favor for a friend whose spouse just graduated from dental school. The intricate details of the print make it difficult for my printer to fill in at smaller sizes; it was good enough for my needs but you may need to scale up for better results. Thanks to the work of NEURUS, I was able to create this simply by superimposing the D on their design in Sketchup and adding the jump ring and background/plaque shapes.

author: rce2

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7I9oeTj3eoF
Tools To Collimate A Newtonian Telescope

I needed a large model to make for my kids. Couldn't find any good ones, so i found a decent one and ran it through MakePrintables autofix. Turned out okay but it lacks a few details.
I have removed the landing gear but not the weaponry.
Oh and it is scaled up to 80cm from nose to tail.
I made it into several smaller pieces. Prints turn out okay.

!!!!! BIG WARNING!!! This model is not PERFECT! Check your slicer for unwanted holes!!!
Most holes closes in my slicer, but i get some small ones on the front wings by the rudders.

The model was originally made by Anders Lejczak! Big thanks!
http://www.colacola.se/expo_viggen.htm

description.text: I'm working on a project with a lot of WS2812B LED's. I designed this rig to help test them in an efficient manner. I used an Arduino Pro Mini to switch between red, green, and blue to ensure each diode works before I install it. If the wires are run through the cap and spaced correctly, you should just have to lay the LED on top to test it.

remixed_from.title: E3D Titan Aero Standard Toolhead for LulzBot TAZ

title: E3D Titan Aero "Mirror" Toolhead for LulzBot Taz
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The E3D Titan Aero extruder prints both solid and flexible filaments, and is available for either 3mm or 1.75mm filament.
www.itworks3d.com created this updated version of their successful E3D Titan Aero toolhead for LulzBot TAZ https://itworks3d.com/product/lulzbot-taz-e3d-titan-aero-toolhead/ to improve filament cooling with a surround filament cooling duct, reduce weight with a smaller stepper motor, and simplify its construction. This design uses the "mirrored" E3D Titan Aero extruder. Our prior designs used the "standard" Titan Aero.
Have our prior toolhead? https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2400804 We offer upgrade options to this new design!: https://itworks3d.com/product/upgrade-earlier-titan-aero-toolhead/
For more information, to purchase a built and tested toolhead, and for a list of the items you need to built your own, visit our site https://itworks3d.com/product/lulzbot-taz-e3d-titan-aero-toolhead/

author: ITWorks

description.text:
I saw a picture of a chess drinking game on the web (see attached pic) and wanted to make my own. So I quickly modelled the parts and startet printing. Overall there are 32 parts to be printed. I have only printed 20 yet. The others should follow soon. Into the figurines fits a volume of 20 ml. So they are the standard size of a shot. Queen and King are slightly bigger, so they are biig shots! :) Feel free to give critique in the comment section below!
Have fun, don't drink too much!! :D If you enjoy my work, I would appreciate a small bitcoin donation to 1MSachsBbZJjBg83nEsTv95oLuQmnmZnGu.

The chess game is scaled so that you can print the Chessboard picture (see the attached pictures) on a DinA4 page in full scale and the figurines fit. So they all fit in a sqare with the sides 2.5 cm long.
I would recommend to use different colors for the different sides! :)
Also I found that to make sure it is water tight you should use 3 extra shells on all layer types, and you should slightly increase the infill perimeter overlap (I use 0.3 on my huxley) and slightly decrease the infill width over thickness (I use 1.5 on my huxley). Additionally I would recommend using an overall infill solidity of 0.3 to 0.4 that gave me the best results. Also you should at least use 3 solid layers. I use 4.

comments.text:
Ahhh, drunken chess has given me many fond memories.
I had a friend that her plan was to take as many pieces of mine in the first part of the game, getting me drunk and blitzing me...
Only way she could win....
comments.author: Nickademusss

description.text: This is a remix of the original bust by Wgss, remodelled for dual extrusion. Eyes and hair  + base were cut out and are on their own, I figured the eyes would look cool in black too.. I've included the .Thing file and the seperate STL. I printed this test at .30mm with obviously black and red ABS, printed at 10%infill, rafts  - Print time approx 3-4 hours.

comments.text: Just some notes if anyone wants to print this, as I tried once unsuccessfully and wasted alot of plastic. Use the Makerware dual extrusion! In case you didn't know,  it creates nice fake surrounding supports which allow the dribble from your nozzles to be knocked off on each pass. That was the only way I could get it to do a clean dual extrusion, either that or physically build thin walls to do the same thing, but i like makerwares fake dribble walls, as they are super thin and print really fast and do the job well.

description.text: Test

print_settings.Notes:: I HIGHLY recommend PLA for these reels - but don't store them in a hot car! I've personally printed reels in PLA, ABS, PETG and Nylon. I've also had one printed in stainless steel at a service. Many of my followers have printed the reel in other materials including acetal, various filled filaments or other printing technologies like SLS.

description.text:
This is it, the original, completely 3D printed fly fishing reel developed by me (aka The Eclectic Angler) and featured in Field & Stream Magazine's Hook Shots video by Joe Cermele (watch the video!) This reel was also recognized by the American Fly Fishing Museum as the first 3D printed (and functional) fly reel and the lightest 4wt fly reel. It was featured in their quarterly The American Fly Fisher journal in 2015.

I started designing the reel in 2012 and, after a year, it was ready to fish. I continued to refine the design over four years to this version 6 design - learning from feedback from several thousand anglers who have downloaded and printed one and from the nearly five hundred reels I've printed myself. It is the best yet.

I have always made the STLs available on my website (for free) at The Eclectic Angler (there is more info, history, and photos there too). But today, I am making the files open source under the Creative Commons - BY-SA license for all to learn from, modify and enjoy.

These reels are a challenging print project but I've designed the parts to be "tolerance tolerant" - meaning that even if your 3D printer is not calibrated perfectly or you don't have mad slicing skills, the parts will still assemble into a smoothly functioning reel! Advanced 3D printers and designers may learn a few tricks to improve their skills too. The detailed Instructions PDF includes lots of tips for slicing and assembling the reel. Please read it, I've found that every question I'm asked has already been answered in the document! You might learn a thing or two about slicing too.

Even if you don't fly fish, the reel is a great stress reliever and showpiece. It makes a satisfying clicking sound that is calming. So print one and post your photos!

About the FIles

Firstly, read the detailed instructions, they explain everything!

I've included files for several different aesthetic and functional options. In a nutshell, these are:

Aesthetic Options
The back plate has 2 options: ported or plain unported
The spool plates each have 2 options: ported or plain unported

You can mix and match these to create different looking reels.

Mechanical Options
There are three options for the click check:

  • left-hand retrieve
  • right-hand retrieve
  • symmetrical

And there are several parts with different size options of parts to help you get a perfect fit:

  • three foot sizes
  • three click spindle sizes

Notes:

See the detailed instructions PDF for slicing tips and assembly instructions.

I HIGHLY recommend PLA for these reels - but don't store them in a hot car! I've personally printed reels in PLA, ABS, PETG and Nylon. I've also had one printed in stainless steel at a service. Many of my followers have printed the reel in other materials including acetal, various filled filaments or other printing technologies like SLS.
See the detailed instructions PDF for assembly instructions. You will need a little super glue and lubricant.

Development of the 3D Printed Fly Fishing Reel

In late 2012 I began design work on a 3D printed fly reel and set some goals for this project:

  • all parts had to be 3D printed, no extra hardware or screws allowed
  • have a pleasing design and not look clunky
  • the parts needed to be small and simple enough for most consumer 3D printers to print
  • parts count as low as possible
  • printable and fishable in PLA - a renewable (made from corn starch), biodegradable plastic
  • glue was allowed
  • have a click check
  • fit modern fly rod reel seats
  • and, the reel had to catch fish!

The first prototype (alpha reel) took a year to create working off and on and working through design problems as they arose. The alpha reel had seven parts, a silent (friction) check, and was printed in ABS. A photo of it is attached below and the original is now in the permanent collection of the American Museum of Fly Fishing in Manchester, Vt.

The alpha reel had some design issues though. The foot had a flat bottom and would not fit into a reel seat without machining first. It was also glued on to the frame's foot pillar - a weak mechanical joint. The spool was printed in two pieces and required reaming to fit the spindle. It was a good first effort though! It also got me a mention in 3D Printing Industry where I was described as an innovative designer!

I quickly got to work on version 2 (beta reel) that incorporated a click check and addressed some of the flaws in the alpha reel. A CAD rendering appears below.

The beta reel has a simple click check that is similar to the click checks I developed for my aluminum and brass fly reel kits. It also has a greatly improved foot that fits reel seat hardware and is securely attached to the frame.

I also started experimenting with techniques to improve the reel's surface finish and overall aesthetics. Unlike most 3D printed parts, the faces that adhere to the printer's bed is visible on these reels. Parts are printed one layer at a time and the first layer is usually imperfect because it is difficult to print perfectly and it picks up any texture or imperfections from the print bed. In most parts, this surface is not usually seen. I started experimenting with exposing the internal fill pattern so it becomes part of the design as you can see in some of the photos.

Several of the 3D slicers (the software used to convert the 3D drawings called STL files into the g-code that controls the printer) have interesting fill patterns like honeycomb (Slic3r) and rounded (KISSlicer). I love KISS's rounded infill - that's what I used for the black and gold reel in the photo above. It took quite a bit of redesign and experimenting to be able to print strong parts with the infill exposed like this but it was worth effort! Many PLA filaments are translucent and allow the internal fill pattern to show through, this rounded pattern looks great with these parts too.

Through 2014 I refined the design and gave the files to 25 fly fishers/3D printer enthusiasts to test out and print reels. I've learned a lot about improving the mechanical design as well as the reel's aesthetics. Over the last few weeks, I used this knowledge in a major overhaul of the reel design - Version 5.

In early 2017, I completed development of the Version 6 reel presented here. It has many new and innovative design features including:

  • stronger and easier to print ovalized pillars
  • asymmetric click check for right- or left-hand retrieves
  • improved foot location index
  • conical spindle base for lower rotating friction
  • stronger handle attachment

I hope you enjoy printing and fishing this reel and please post comments or questions.

The alpha reel Beta reel rendering Exposed infill Version 6 reel

comments.text: I'm a little confused on the cooling side of this.
comments.author: joshz

comments.text:
The fan cooling the Titan Aero heatsink is a 5v on our toolhead. The blower fan that is the filament cooler is 24V.
We substitute in a 5v heatsink cooling fan for the clear 24V included in the Aero kit to make it compatible with LulzBots. Want a deal on one of the OE 24V 40mm fans? We have them here https://itworks3d.com/product/fan-24v-40x40x10mm/
There's a parts list with model numbers and links that calls out the 5V and 24V for the fans on the product page under "What parts do I need to build my own E3D Titan Aero toolhead for the LulzBot TAZ?" at https://itworks3d.com/product/lulzbot-taz-e3d-titan-aero-toolhead/

title: PLIGHTRI - a Tricopter with mounting for Naze FC board
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Built this for my home-built tricopter, inspired by David Windestahl's design (RC-Explorer)
New update coming

  • Aimed towards a modular design I'm working on setting up my printer first, as soon as I've a confirmed good print and flight test I'll post the update. Let me know by request what kind of flight controller board you want to be able to mount - this will allow for a one-fits all design!

  • fits 10mm booms
  • screw holes let you screw in M3 bolts directly in the plastic
  • DT750 motor mounts for 10mm booms - including rear hinged setup
  • Naze 32 and Acro Naze 32 mounting case bottom from Gruffy
  • enclosed battery holder - protects your soft lipo in case of a crash
  • camera mount for Sony Action Cam platform on the front
  • non-folding legs
  • printed with supports
    printed at 10% density .2mm resolution and it's solid. The "fishtail" towards the back is intended as surface on which to mount LEDs.
    next version will probably include cable-management clips and possibly a new removable leg system
    This battery holder is supposed to just "clip in" to the chassis.
    After having just concluded a test flight with the battery holder in place, I can confirm that it performs as promised. It perfectly fits my 3S 2200mAh. I can, upon request scale/resize the container part to accomodate larger batteries. However for my purposes the 2200mAh is more than sufficient for 10-15 minute flights, even with the Sony Action cam mounted on board.

Designed the piece with Blender. Built it mostly with boolean logic - built the hole pattern of the Acro NaZe (a square pattern with 3mm holes), added the Sony ActionCam base plate from ViniG (see sources), and built from there.
Decided I wanted plenty of options to hold a battery and cables into place, and figured on using a velcro strap for it, maybe two.
Printed it on a Replicator 2 at 10% infill and .2mm slice thickness and supports. You'll need the supports, if not for the camera mount, then at least for the boom "bays".
The thing is rock solid, but I think the boom "placeholders" were shrunk down a bit, needed to trim my booms a bit to fit. Drilled holes through the booms to insert M3x20mm screws to hold them in place. It's not going anywhere. The plastic holes are just the right size that you can screw directly into the plastic without damaging the print or feel them getting loose.
I hope others find this useful. Also if you want a different camera mount on it, please let me know - it's more then easy enough to swap it out and make a copied design.
The motor mounts are meant for DT750s, I basically built them a little "light" so they're a tad springy when having a rough landing. Better to have to replace a landing gear segment than a motor mount.
The hinged mount is supposed to be hinged on 2x M3x20mm bolts. The holes in the "rear motor assembly" part are slightly larger than the "rear motor support's", so that you can screw the bolts into the fixed part while the articulation remains the same on the mounts.

title: Mayan Calendar Mold - Low Melt Metal Lost PLA - Chocolate or Soap Mold

description.text:
Inspired by this guy and his low melt METAL molds,
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26500
and some to this guy for starting me on the coding
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31581
and this guy, for taking it to the next level (HiTemp-LostPLA)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:82176 I chose this scan of a Mayan calender because it has a incredible amount of detail and I want to see how much sticks. Plus this started as a 3D scan (by someone else) and I want to learn ways to apply those scans. This 3D scan was massive, it choked my computer so hard I did most of my mold making with a blob the same size, so my render wouldn't take 1/2hr v1 is meant to print flat, - quick and easy v2, meant to print standing up to get better detail, but will take longer to print, and another just like it with supports. (those are not peace signs) I have more low melt molds coming soon. If printed in something flexible, this mold could be used as a Chocolate or Soap Mold with no problem. Please Try it :-) v1 on both seems a little shallow at small scale, (see printed mold2 w/o supports) so I made a deeper one for mold2, this time. For this deep I am going to use the supports. for my first print, I printed verticle-square-no supports. came out fast and proper.

• select mold.
    If you want quick, use m1 (its round)
    If you want best resolution, use m2 with supports.

  • Load and rotate, I use replicatorG
    if m1, make it center, face up, largest scale you can.
    if m2, make it center, and put the arms to the ground...like a peace sign

  • Settings
    I am still working on that. i will let you know.

  • Plastic
    use ABS if you can, higher melt point, I am using PLA to start. if you want to do soap/chocolate/candles (this shape would make a poor candle) try this material
    http://www.makergeeks.com/flsofi.html
    No I have no yet tried HIPS or PVA

  • After Print
    Follow direction for the type of low-melt metal...or chocolate, soap, whatever.
    Pour
    Cool
    Remove (to dissolve abs/pla acetone bath, for HIPS use Limone, for PVA you can use water.

description.text:
This swerve drive, nominally designed for FRC competition, is a lighter weight, but vastly simplified, version of my earlier swerve drive (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1135618). It is almost completely 3D printable. The heart of this design is the integrated low-profile steering bearing that uses 6mm Airsoft pellets as bearing balls. It also uses a twisted timing belt to simplify the mechanics.

Note that this design is for very lightweight robots - I wouldn't recommend a total weight per wheel of more than 20 lb or so. (The swerve unit itself weighs about 5 lbs.) It is also intended to be very fast - up to 20ft/sec! The wheel tread should be grippy enough for good acceleration, but you won't win and pushing wars. In fact, if you make the tread any grippier, you run the risk of breaking components in a collision (rather than the wheels just sliding on the carpet).

Also note: This design has only gone through very preliminary testing. As we do some more abusive testing, I'll post those results here.

UPDATE: So far, we've hooked it up and driven it around a little. Everything is operating quite smoothly so far. Next up is getting our full swerve drive control implemented so that we can really beat on it!

Printer:

UDIO

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Print all parts with 4 perimeter lines, 4 solid top and bottom layers, and use a full triangular infill (3 sets of infill lines on each layer). After printing, clean up and blobs on any mating surface. And on the bearing race in particular, sand smooth any blobs or lumps left from printing.

Bill of Materials

3D Printed Parts:
base plate
steering pulley
axle support
idler block
bearing inner race (steering bearing)
wheel
18 tooth, 8mm bore pulley (drive motor)
18 tooth, 6mm bore pulley (steering motor)

Fabricated Parts (see Solidworks model):
2 0.250"dia, 0.75L steel pins (idler block)
2 0.500" aluminum axle (wheel axle)
2 0.625 dia steel idler rollers (idler block)

Purchased Parts:
1 CIM motor (drive)
2 AndyMark CIM motor heatsink (drive motor)
1 NeveRest motor w/ 20:1 planetary gearhead & encoder (steering)
1 AMT-103 encoder (drive motor)
50 (approx) 6mm dia airsoft BB's (steering bearing)
1 104 tooth 3mm pitch GT3 belt (drive belt)
1 125 tooth 3mm pitch GT3 belt (steering belt)
1 608 bearing (steering idler bearing)
2 0.500" bore x 1.125" OD flanged bearing (wheel)

Fasteners:
8 8-32 nuts (6 for base plate, 2 for steering pulley)
1 10-32 nut (steering pulley)
1 3/8" washer (steering pulley)
1 1/4" washer (steering pulley)
4 M3 washer (steering motor)
2 #8 washers (steering idler bearing)
1 #10 washer (idler block)
2 0.25" bore by 0.010" thick shim washer (idler rollers)
1 1/4-20 x 1/2" hex head screw (axle)
1 10-32 x 1.425L socket head cap screw (idler block)
6 8-32 x 1/2" pan head screw (steering bearing inner race)
2 8-32 x 5/8" socket head cap screw (axle support)
1 8-32 x 1/2" pan head screw (idler block jack screw)
1 8-32 x 3/4" flathead screw (steering idler bearing)
2 4-40 x 5/16" flathead screw (encoder)
2 10-32 x 1/2" flathead screw (CIM motor)
4 M3 x 14mm screw (steering motor)
1 1/2" external retaining ring (axle)
1 2mm square key (CIM motor)
2 8-32 x 0.25" set screw (18t pulleys)

Assembly

The assembly process follows the posted photos

Photo 3: Start with the Steering Pulley. On the underside, press in the 10-32 nut into the center nut cavity and two 8-32 nuts in the cavities on either side.

Photo 4: Position the inner race so that the ball access holes line up and insert all 40 airsoft pellets in-between the races. (Note I originally designed a cover for the access hole, but the balls are actually really hard to get out even without the cover.)

Photo 5: Press six 8-32 nuts in the hex cavities in the base plate.

Photo 6: Assemble the CIM motor into the base plate with the 2 10-32 flathead screws. (Note the photos shows the 2mm key int hte keyway, but this doesn't go in until later.)

Photo 7: Modify the encoder base plate for 4-40 flathead screws by drilling the holes out to 0.110" dia. and then countersinking for the screwheads. Screw the encoder base to the base plate. (Note, the motor is not shown in this photo.)

Photo 8: Finish assembling the encoder as per the AMT-103 encoder instructions. At this point, you can put the key in the CIM motor shaft keyway.

Photo 9: There's not really any room for much of a connector, so solder the encoder wires directly to the encoder pins. It is not shown, but I then insulated the ends with a blob of hot melt glue. Snake the free end of the encoder cable underneath the face of the motor. You may need to loosen the motor to get the cable shoved through.

Photo 10: Assemble the steering bearing inner race to the base plate using the six 8-32 x 1/2" screws. For each screw, you'll need to rotate the bearing so that the access slot aligns with the screw hole.

Photo 11: Press the beveled ends of the two 1/4" pins into the idler block. Orient the pins so that the beveled faces press against each other inside the block.

Photo 12: Put one 1/4" shim washer on each pin. Apply a little grease to each pin and then slide the idler rollers onto the pins. The grease should be sticky enough to hold the rollers in place during assembly.

Photo 13: Slide the 18t pulley onto the CIM shaft (hub first), aligning the keyway in the pulley with the key. The end of the pulley should be about 1/10" past the end of the motor shaft. Secure with an 8-32 set screw. (Note: you will first need to tap an 8-32 thread in the pulley hub.) Next, put the 104 tooth belt over the pulley and screw the idler block down over the protruding ends of the belt using the long 10-32 screw and a washer. Note the belt twists so that the flat side of the belt rides on the idler roller.

Photo 14: Press the 1/2" bore bearings into either side of the wheel. Assemble the retaining ring into the groove on the axle.

Photo 15: Shove the axle through the wheel bearings, slip the 3/8" washer over the end of the axle and then push the axle through the hole in the steering pulley. Secure the axle in place with the 1/4-20 hex head screw and the 1/4" washer.

Photo 16: Insert the 8-32 x 1/2" jack screw into the side of the idler block but leave it barely engaged. Push the idler block all the way in so that the belt has the maximum of slack. Slip the belt up onto the pulley. Slide the axle support over the free end of the axle and secure in place with the two 8-32 socket head cap screws. Finally, carefully tighten the 8-32 jack screw to push the idler block out to tension the belt.

Photo 17: Screw the NeveRest gear motor to the base plate with the 4 M3 screws and washers. Slide the 18t pulley with the 6mm bore onto the motor shaft and secure with an 8-32 set screw.

Photos 18,19: Assemble the steering belt idler bearing to the base plate with the 8-32 flathead screw and two #8 washers.

Photo 20: Slip the 125 tooth belt over the wheel assembly, over the motor pulley and under the idler bearing. Loosen the 4 motor screws slightly and slide the motor back to tension the belt and re-tighten the screws.

Not Shown: Slip the two CIM motor heat sinks over the CIM motor and secure with a large zip tie. Position the head sinks as close to the base plate as possible without touching it. The CIM motors can get pretty hot, and without heatsinks, they will melt the base plate plastic. Even with the heatsinks, you should check to make sure your motors are not getting more than warm to the touch. Also note that if your motor is getting hot, it may be softening the pulley on the motor shaft. If so, you may need to switch to an aluminum pulley.

Photos 1,2: The base plate is designed with an integral channel for connection to 1" square aluminum frame members using heavy-duty zip ties. To keep the aluminum tubes form pulling out, you may want to stick a screw into the side of the tube just adjacent to the zip tie
so that the screw head will catch on the zip tie if it tries to pull out. Note that I used zip ties because they offer a certain amount of compliance to the frame to help absorb energy in a collision.

comments.text: VERY nice work!!  Thanks for sharing.
comments.author: MadTooler

comments.text: Unfortunately we haven't done a huge amount of testing so far because our FRC team decided to go with a different drive system this year.  I fatigue on the belt is directly related to the load on the belt (pre-load plus dynamic load).  Both of these can be minimize if the mass of the robot being driven is lowered.  My gut feeling, though, is that for an FRC competition robot, which only gets run for a few hours to 10's of hours total, belt failure will not be a problem, and if there is the occasional belt failure, they are easy (and relatively cheap) to replace.  The bigger limitation is the torque that can be delivered through the relatively tiny 6mm wide, 3mm pitch belt before the teeth start to skip on the small pulley.
comments.author: MadTooler

comments.text: Thanks for the extra details.  My immediate applications are mostly interactive roaming robots to perform within crowds, such as museums and stores.  Low speed and gentle navigation would be the typical operation, lending to less stress on the belts, but if this could still result in changing belts every 10 or 20 hours, that would be a drag.
comments.author: LoboCNC

comments.text: With a 60 lb robot with low speeds and low accelerations, I don't think you'd have any problems with the belts.  We haven't had any problem with skipping teeth.  The trick is to set the pre-load just high enough to cover the needed accelerations but no higher.  That will minimize the stress on the core fibers on the outer edges of the belt.  Your other option would be to use urethane belts with a kevlar core.  They are more flexible and would be much less prone to failure, and the small loss of stiffness would not be a big issue for your application.

comments.text: The 3D printed bearing with airsoft BB's is certainly accurate enough for this application, but the big worry is that it will break during impact with another robot (or a wall). Unfortunately, commercial large bore slew bearings like this, that are very flat and with mounting holes, are generally non-stock items and very expensive. My other swerve drive design, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1135618, uses a custom machined split-race bearing. When I get a chance, I'll be posting a hybrid design that is still mostly 3D printed, but that uses the machined steel bearing instead.

comments.text: First off, I have no robot building experience, so take the following with as many grains of salt as needed.
comments.author: DigitalMonk

comments.text: Thanks for the tip on using Armadillo filament.  I hadn't heard of this, but it looks like it prints and reasonable temperatures, has low shrinkage (warping), and is actually a little stiffer than PLA (important for structural parts).  It's yield strength is not as high as PLA, but the added toughness may make up for that.  It's main drawback, though, might be it's heat deflection temperature which appears to be lower than that for PLA. Polycarbonate would be a great material, however its high printing temperature and greater shrinkage make it more difficult for the uninitiated to print with.  We'll be doing more testing with the PLA and see exactly what failures we run into.  I've also got a version of this swerve drive that is nearly identical, but that uses the machined steel slew bearing from my first swerve drive, if it turns out bearing failure is the main issue.

comments.text: What kind of tools would be required to fabricate the metal parts? Can it be done without a lathe?
comments.author: CaptObvious

comments.text: As designed, the axle and the idler rollers require some simple lathe work.  I'd like to do a little redesign so that axle can be made from stock materials without a lathe. The idler rollers are a little trickier - you could just use a bronze bushing, but you really need flanges on both sides.  Our high school does have a lathe, but a crappy one, so I end up doing lathe work for the team at home - thus I'm totally motivated to make this lathe-free.
comments.author: CaptObvious

comments.text: Great job with these wheels.  I'm also without a lathe, having a version that does not require metalwork would make this project far more accessible.

description.text:
Needed to drill 16 holes for 3/8" wood dowels for a project. Looked for a jig to do so. Jigs for 3/8" only had no way to easily and accurately place them (and were $20). Jigs that did provide spacing were usually multi-size and cost $70-100+!

Ah ha!! I have a 3D printer! So twenty minutes later, using Sketchup, I had a design. Two and a half hours later, I had a jig. All I need to do is clamp it to the board and drill.

How long will it last? We'll see. (Drilled all 16 holes with little wear!) For $0.40 worth of PLA I can make as many as it takes and still be way ahead.

In the lack of a good speaker foot/mount, I decided to make something original. This is what it ended up being. At first I was a little afraid of the balance, but it turned out great. Easy and straight forwards ;)

Print out one center piece and three of each of the feet and heads. Use 6mm steal rods for the assembly. I added a piece of double sided tape to fix the contraption to the speakers. Although this is not strictly necessary, it made the whole thing easier to handle (e.g. moving the speakers around).

title: CTC DIY Prusa i3 Clone Display Cover

description.text:
Infos zum Drucken des CTC DIY Prusa i3 Clone Displaygehäuses

Gedruck wird auf die Glassoberfläche. Dazu wird das Bett auf 65°C aufgeheitzt. Nach Beendigung der ersten Schicht muss diese mit Tesafilm an den dafür vorhergesehenen Flächen (Ecken & Mittelstücke) fixiert werden, sonst wird der Druck nicht gelingen! Dazu die Druckgeschwindigkeit auf Minimum setzten und die Filmstreifen aufkleben. Danach kann wieder auf die normale Druckgeschwindigkeit beschleunigt werden.

Zur Befestigung des fertigen Displaygehäuses werden 2 Gummies in die Nut um das Display gespannt. (siehe Foto)

Viel Spass beim Drucken...

This is a remix of spiridios's customizable socket rail, thanks for the excellent design!

I have added a few options to provide:

  1. dovetail to help connecting multiple short rail into a long one
  2. screw mounting hole instead of hanger, in case you wish to mount it onto tool wall or drawer.
  3. Add side mount option, to allow the rail to mount in shallow drawers and have the sockets pointing sideway.

Both the dovetail and screw hole have some option to allow you to customize to fit your need.

Enjoy!

author: pachubruno

description.text:
DIY Interactive synthesiser for parties, etc. that emits digital sounds that go together and create a social communal experience.

HOW TO PLAY?

  • Blowing activates polytones (sound), determines length of the tone as well.
  • Each hose will activate a different “musical instrument”.
    The aim is to have fun, learn how to code, 3d print and use the Arduino.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

15%

PROGRAMS USED TO CREATE THIS OBJECT

Solid works 2017
Rhinoceros 5

HOW TO KNOW MORE ABOUT CODING?
  • For more informaion about Arduino:
    https://www.arduino.cc/en/Tutorial/HomePage

  • For more informaion about Firmata:
    https://www.arduino.cc/en/Reference/Firmata

  • For more information about Maxuino:
    http://www.maxuino.org/archives/category/tutorials

HOW TO MAKE YOUR OWN PROTOTYPE?

  • Download the STL files.

  • 3D print the objects shown in the picture below.

  • Put the Arduino board and the speaker in the lower part.

  • Connect the sensor, tube (10 mm) and mouthpiece as shown in the pictures from the four sides.

  • Assemble the parts together by inserting a plastic cylinder in the middle (15 mm - L 350 mm).

  • Connect it to the computer and blow to activate the sounds.

PRODUCT COMPONENTS
  • Arduino.
  • 3D printed parts.
  • Four microphones.
  • Flexible tubes.
  • Plastic cylinder.
  • Computer.

description.text:
This is a small Christmas tree decoration shaped like a tree that could be stood up on it's own or hung on a tree by a string. Originally, this tree was designed to sell at my daughter's school Christmas market to raise funds for her class.

You can print it in whatever colour and material you like, but I chose clear ABS for the star, green ABS for the foliage and red ABS for the base.

To complete the model as I have you will also need some 3mm carbon fibre rod which is easy to come by via eBay. The lengths of rod that I found worked best were 15mm and 30mm. I've designed a special jig to help with the cutting that can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2680643

I've included STLs for the shafts, but I can pretty much guarantee they'll snap during assembly.

The tree should assemble without glue and it gives a nice tight fit. I reckon it might be a good idea to add a blob of glue if hanging it on a tree to keep it all together.

You can scale the STLs up by 133% to give a bigger model that uses 4mm rod. This gives a much more robust tree but nearly triples the print time. The cutting jig for 4mm rod is here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2682013

Some barbeque skewer sticks are 3mm in diameter, these might work for the shafts if cut to the right length.

I'd really appreciate to see any makes on this page.

MERRY CHRISTMAS!!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10% where applicable

Notes:

Don't print the full tree unless you have a sintering machine. I've only included ths STL to show what the model looks like.

Shafts inserted into the tree foliage

Be very careful when inserting the rods and make sure the tree top or bottom are on a table as it's very brittle indeed.

Designed with FreeCAD 0.16, Voronator.com and Blender

The outline shape of the tree foliage was designed in FreeCAD 0.16, which was then exported as an STL to voronator.com which processed the shape into the Voronated wire-mesh shape.

I then designed the central shaft to give the model vertical strength and merged it with the Voronated foliage in Blender.

I then designed the base and the star in FreeCAD.

title: Reptile S800 Flight Controller and OLED display holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This is my first attempt at creating and printing a thing from scratch. I wanted a thing to hold my Flight Controller stack and an OLED display in my Reptile S800 SkyShadow flying wing. I tried to design it to allow room for cables, airflow, and to fit the bay without modification. I think this works pretty well. In my set-up it's holding a PDB, FC, and GPS on the main stack, plus the OLED screen. It fits in the bay and the lid closes without any need for modification. This version weighs about 8g; I have also created a light weight version at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2699975 which weighs about 5g.

Notes:

Apologies for the orientation of the object. Fusion 360 had the Y axis set to top by default, I have now remedied this, but for the correct orientation with this print, please rotate the X axis by -90 degrees in your slicer.

I printed this on my Prusa i3 Mk1 in PLA. My settings were:

Brim: 2
Material: 1.75 mm
Nozzle: 0.4
Layer height: 0.20
infill: 20% (though I used 10% on an earlier test print and it worked fine)
Bed temp: 50 C (70 C first layer)
Nozzle temp: 210 C (215 C first layer)
Speed: 40mm/s (60% first layer)

This printed absolutely fine for me, and it was my first real print. The only thing you will need to do is chase the M3 threads with a tap. The threads were close to being usable straight off the printer, but the tap makes life much easier.
Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360

author: DarrenLines

description.text:
I was suspecting that my 3D printer was printing things 2% too small. As if the steps-per-mm for X and Y were too small. 
This is hardly possible because some pretty reliable calculations can give you that number to many decimal places....

Print this and measure the distance from the top of the L to the part sticking out at the bottom. 
Oh! If, after printing this, you're still not satisfied that your movement calibration is accurate, you can rotate it 90 degrees for testing in the other axis. (This would make sense on a reprap which has different mechanisms for X and Y movement. )
The cutout near the corner of the L is there to ensure that both measurement surfaces are approached from the same side. Any hysteresis should cancel out like this. If you print it at 1.0 scale, it should come out at 100mm. 
(I've improved it slightly since printing it, so you'll get the improved version over the one in the photograph.)
I've printed it with 30% fill, 3 layers of bottom and top thickness at 0.2mm layer height.

comments.text: All plastics shrink as they cool.  They're extruded hot, and usually onto a heated bed.

title: Glass Bed Plate Corner Clamps CR-10

description.text:
I hate using binder clips!

I made my glass plate clamps built into the corners with small arms that can swing out of the way to remove glass easily.

***** found a problem with rear right arm hitting lower x gantry roller when doing automatic level from screen menu.

please use the gcode included for leveling, this avoids the rear right arm.
CR10LevellerX.gcode

big thanks to Don Stauffer for the leveling code basis!!!!

You need to print the 4 corners ( print body LF RR twice, all others one each) and arms and cover in a heat resistant plastic (I used PETG)
Use supports, and 60% infill

the part TPUtube should be printed in TPU (I use ninjaflex with 50% infill)

You will need 4 screws M3 socket head by 16mm minimum, 20 mms should be fine. and M3 nuts

Please note that I made this for my machine which has heat insulation under bed so I left allowance for the thickness, and my glass plate which is smaller than the aluminum bed (300mm x 300mm)

You may remix to your needs, please give me credit for original.

If you make it, please post your photos!

description.text:
Just a quick forward: I used a piece of bowden tubing to go from the small guide hole to the extruder as it is such a sharp bend. This allows it to work, but without it it may not work so well. (Being that this design may not work the best, I have designed a new version that requires use of an old harddrive bearing/spindle. It may work better for some! https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2776254)

My class got an Anycubic i3 Mega and I wanted a spool holder that would integrate into the Anycubic i3 Mega instead of having the external acrylic holder. So, I came up with this idea and utilized I-Beam structure for the support of the arm. It should allow spools up to 100mm wide and 250mm in diameter. In addition, the center hole diameter can be 2" or larger. The symbol on the plate is something that identifies my engineering class as makers. Enjoy!

FYI, the stock screws will not work with this print. I have aligned the holes to match those of the stock screw holes (with some extra height adjustment), but you will need screws that are 3mm longer than stock. I believe the stock screws are M3x5 and need to be M3x8.

Printer:

Anycubic i3 Mega

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20% or more

Notes:

Choose your own settings for resolution and infill. I would recommend the settings mentioned above. Get 8mm length screws. Also, to ensure flatness, you may want to use a heated bed and a brim.

description.text:
This vest is compatible with the OpenBCI M4 Ultracortex system. This was created initially as an aesthetic complement to the starkly functional-looking M4 headset. It can (hypothetically) accommodate adjustable spring-loaded dry electrodes for bio-measurement. The vest applies the same design method to create node arrays that hold threaded inserts, which are printed flat and glued in. I've included the inserts and bolts in this listing. Two hundred and twenty inserts are needed to fill all nodes. The threaded insert can then hold the adjustable "Octabolt" which can hold a sensor or electrode. The inserts are needed where a section boundary passes through the nodes in order to join the sections, but are otherwise only needed if you actually intend to populate the node with a bolt. For the bolts to be functional, they would require springs and electrodes (non 3D-printed) as described in the OpenBCI documentation. Other M4 related files are available in the M4 Dev Kit:
https://github.com/OpenBCI/Ultracortex/tree/master/Mark_IV/DevKit

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm should work.

Infill:

30-50%

Notes:

The sectioned model is designed to be printed on a larger format FDM printer with a ~300mm (12 inch) bed. Each section is about 280mm on its longest axis, and about 240mm on the second longest, with the shortest axis presumed to be oriented approximately vertical for best strength and fastest printing.

TPU, Nylon, or another semi-rigid material is suggested for the main vest structure for wearability. The inserts should be printed of a solid material like PLA or ABS.

I did not make this 3d model. The original 3d model was derived from the video game "Aliens vs. Predator". This is for personal use only and is not to be used for profit. It has been modified for printing purposes only. I might make a modified hatched version in the near future, so stay tuned. Cheers.

description.text:
There are few nice boxes here that adjust to any size. I frequently need small boxes to hide electronic components in for better WAF.
So I finally made a snaphook-type box design that can be scaled as needed.
You will need freeCAD to use the parametric design. The STL files are just a demo for a box that will contain a 433MHz receiver snugly.

What plane is above my head, when is the next bus leaving, what is the actual exchange rate to USD, how long does it take home with the current traffic jam, ……. and of course what’s the weather tomorrow? All those and much more information’s can be fetched from the internet and displayed on your desk.

To catch such things from internet API’s become very easy with chips as an ESP8266 programmed on the Arduino IDE. But as not every maker is a master from day one, there are a lot of people offering already programmed examples in the net. They can be adapted to the own needs with only low effort. For example Dani (https://blog.squix.org/) is one of them. He has also complete kits which make the start easier for those which are not highly experienced in soldering electronics. This horizontal TFT display is based on one of them, the ESP8266 WiFi Color Display Kit 2.4″. Beside of this only 4 M3 nuts and 4 M3x20 screws are required.

IMPORTANT NOTE: I realized that I assembled the ESP8266 Wifi Color Display Kit 2.4" slightly different than it's shown in the assemble instruction video on the blog.squix.org page. Instead of using only the male pin headers for the ESP8266 module, I used the male and female pin headers (both in the kit). Please check the picture. If you are using only the male headers the hole for the reset button is wrong located and you require to rasp the connector cutout a bit.

The quite deep electronics and the power socket on the side lead to a pretty big housing. Therefore I tried to design a housing close to the style of the 80ies when the electronics was in general a bit more bulky. This brings a design with a slight vintage touch which I tried to underline with the choice of the grey and white color. I abstain from sanding or treating the plastic with acetone which leads to a texture on the front.

The front sticks to the housing but the socket (in which the power cord is hided) needs to be glued to the housing. For the distance holder on top and bottom a M3 nut needs to be pressed into the holders. The only unhappy thing is the hole for to push the reset switch of the ESP 8266 board. It can be only used if the screw on the bottom right is turned out. This as the switch is located in line with the holes for the distance holder. For the power supply cable which comes with the kit should be used as it has an pretty short stiff length.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%
No sanding or acetone treatment

title: Christmas Stocking Hangers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted something a little better looking than tape or blue tack to hang the stockings on the fire place.
So modelled up these weighted Christmas Stocking Hangers,
I made 5 different Anchor variants so to avoid repeats on your fireplace they are,
HO HO HO, SANTA, JOY, NOEL and Mix Anchor
the Anchor has been designed with 2 x 30mm diameter voids inside them so coins or washers can be dropped inside during the print to add weight, and they all work with the same Hook.
The Hook is best printed on its side so to add inherit strength in the extruded lines and is a nice push fit so no glue is really needed that way if one is broken by your little Elf you don't need to re print the entire anchor.

I printed mine in Fillamentum Signal Red / Green Grass with Gold Happens Details. using the pause at height feature of Cura (I paused mine at 20.5mm high with 0.15mm layer heights) and they came out Great

I printed mine on my CR-10 had had no problems at all with any of the bridges both visible and internal

I hope you enjoy these and if you make any please post pictures, I would love to see them.

Merry Christmas

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I used a pause at height on cura to change the fillament colour for the details
I would suggest that you use a pause at height for the internal void too to give you chance to add teh Coins or Washers

title: Playable Ukulele - Printable w/ no Supports

description.text: Full-size Soprano Ukulele which prints with no supports. Now includes files for both smaller and larger printers. Designed to work with standard guitar or ukulele tuning machines and standard ukulele strings. Playable and is full soprano scale. Many iterations to get to this design including: curved body for strength and to resist warping and Inner bracing which generally prevents delamination. I have been playing my first print for about 6 months without issue. UPDATE: Now includes files for smaller printers. Body lower and upper and Neck lower and upper. I included tabs on the body and neck to try and make glueing up the pieces easier. Let me know if any issues. Video of playing available at: http://youtu.be/6QZvYGKUjJA

Body  
Use at least 4 layers and 50% fill.  This will ensure that you have sufficient stiffness in the body and structure supports to hold the string tension.  Printing from the inside out general works best for the initial overhang which is the roughest part of the print.   
Neck   
Like the body use lots of layers on the outside (at least 4).  For the neck I have had success with 50% fill, but wouldn't do any less to ensure you have sufficient strength for strings.  
Now includes files for small printers.  Upper and Lower Body and Upper and Lower neck.  Super glue the parts all together once printed.

This is probably my first big 3d printing project and I learned quite a bit. Some observations and suggestions based upon my experience. first off, amazing job to Solstie, thank you for contributing, were it not for you, I'd never had experienced this. On to the lessons learned
My printer can only do 210/210/185 so I had to do the 4 piece print.
Printed all 4 pieces out in PLA at 210, with a bed heat of 55 at .2 layers and 50% infill
Assembled with Loctite All Purpose GO2 Glue, on the neck i also used Welder, and standard Loctite (black and red bottle). It broke all 3 times. I dremeled 2 holes and added 2 nails with the head cut off for support on that joint.

comments.text:
Thanks for the reply. Yeah, I'm not a sketchup expert either (I use SolidWorks). I did some Google searching and found this:
Sketchup is a “polygonal surface modeling” program, which means that models are made from flat polygon faces – flat surfaces and curves alike. Curves are approximated using many flat faces – for example the default circle in Sketchup has 24 sides. You can see this clearly by turning on Hidden Geometry (View > Hidden Geometry) while looking at a curved surface. Sketchup uses a visual smoothing technique to make the flat segments look like a smooth curve on the computer screen, but when you 3D print a curved surface, the individual faces (or facets) may be visible.
The good news is that the more faces a curve is made of, the smoother it becomes. When using the arc or circle tools, you can set the number of segments to whatever you need. You should increase the number of segments so each individual segment is about 1/32” (1mm) long. Depending on your printer and the material you’re using, the number of segments needed will vary, but for smooth parts this is a good rule of thumb.
From this link:
http://www.mastersketchup.com/8-tips-for-3d-printing-with-sketchup/http://www.mastersketchup.com/...
But that sounds like you would maybe have to re-do parts of the model, unless Sketchup is parametric. Thanks anyway!

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0xBaVG8vXN7
A solar searcher with a decent size. You just need to add a screen made of thin paper to complete it.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hrwW827cFj4

Yagi antenna support parts. These parts were designed to be used with measuring tape as the radiating elements. Both the reflector and directors use the same part while the Driven Element has a special part for itself. The size of the elements and spacing was based on this schematic for 433MHz:
http://www.instructables.com/files/orig/F8H/ZM28/H8XM1W8R/F8HZM28H8XM1W8R.jpg It was also tested and verified. Check instructions for more information.

These parts were printed in a Makerbot 2X with ABS in the lowest settings, with 10% of infill and 3 shells. Also we made it without raft.  
The parts are easily tightened to the boom with zip ties. We also add the SW designs in case anyone wants to adapt it to his own boom size.   
The are 2 holes on each side off the parts that allow do screw fit the measuring tape. The humps in the corners stop the elements from rotating when it is stretched.   
The Driven Element part has a central column that divides the wiring for each side. it also has a small hole that allows the cable to be zip tied against the boom in order to guarantee that everything stays correctly locked.

(UPDATE: added a cup + lid in one part combo since I had some request for it. It has a little cutout in the bottom so you can tie off the loop for the hanger w/o it showing. Print with 20% infill)

This ornament, while not technically a remix, was inspired by another coffee cup Christmas ornament here on Thingiverse, so I want to give that thing a shout out.

Designed from scratch, this is slightly different in that it prints in three parts. This allows the cup to be hollow, and therefore prints much faster (and lighter). Also, it has a printable insulator ring. When you combine materials it can make for a very cool ornament.

Print Settings:

  • Cup and insulator: print at a .4mm wall with 0 infill. This leaves them hollow, but makes for a very fast and sturdy print. I've printed w/ and w/o rafts, ymmv. Layer height up to you.

  • Lid: print at 1.2mm wall thickness, 20% infill. Layer height up to you.

Post Processing:

  • All parts should snap together fairly sturdily, you may wish to add some glue for more stability, but most likely not needed.

  • Add a string through the hole and knot, you may wish to use the included washer to tie your string to so it can't pull through!

Please post your make!

Giant Lego inspired Christmas tree. Simple to print, no support needed. Can print 7, 8 or 9 layers depending on how much time you want to invest (9 does look best though). This is my first model that I've made myself so nothing complicated here. Can be printed with minimal base, walls and stepped infill - especially if you're running out of green filament with two layers still to go...

Doesn't have to be a Christmas tree, can just be a giant Lego pine tree (3471) instead.

I printed on an Anet A8 and the largest layer fits within the print bed (fairly) comfortably.
It sort of snaps together but best to glue the sections together for stability. May need some shaving/trimming where the layers join.

title: ANET A8 interchangeable extruder, fast dismantling

description.text:
Possibility of mounting any extruder on a standard support for ANET A8.
Easy disassembly to repair the fuser outside the printer.
In the trigger that presses the filament it is necessary to mount a bearing 625 rs.
The dimensions of the bearing are 16x5x5 mounted on an axis of 5 mm diameter and 16 mm in length with a washer on each side of the bearing.
The drive gear is an Mk8.

Posibilidad de montar cualquier extrusora en un soporte estándar para ANET A8.
Fácil desmontaje para reparar el fusor fuera de la impresora.
En el gatillo que presiona el filamento hay que montar un rodamiento 625 rs.
Las medidas del rodamiento son 16x5x5 montado en un eje de 5 mm de diametro y 16 mm de longitud con una arandela a cada lado del rodamiento.
El engrane de arrastre es un Mk8.

description.text:
Hi there, i did my very first street art last week and went well.
So now my friend Richard and I will start making this refugees welcome art piece that we envisige could be 3D printed and added to art street and lanes where people would most likely see it and share it on social media.

So the idea is simply to open doors to refugees therefore bringing awareness to the refugee crisis in many parts of the world.

If you'd like to participate please print a family of your choice and print a door, there are many doors to download.
I wanted to be fancy and make my own so you are welcome to use that one if you like.

Also i have added a doormat photo which can be laminated and glued at the foot of the door.
a sign to go over the door is also attached (see white sign)

enjoy and most importantly share it by posting the photo and the exact location.
Richard will make a map shortly so people can see where they are and you can visit them.

In the meantime add the photos here and to instragram

description.text:
This is 3mm spacer to attach to the carriage of the MP Select Mini (verified on the v2) to trigger the y axis endstop with the nozzle farther back. This is needed if the nozzle head is no longer sitting over the build surface (such as when the hotend has been replaced with an authentic e3d v6).

I redesigned seagas' original spacer to be more stable in the x and z axes. Their spacer originally relied on friction to keep the piece from falling or moving around the carriage face. My design moves the clip to above the carriage to add more stability.

Installation:

  • Turn off Printer
  • Move the y-axis carriage forward
  • Slip spacer onto carriage, with the "3" facing forward
  • Push spacer up until slip sits on top of the carriage
  • Adjust in the x axis until it aligns with the Y-axis endstop
  • Turn on 3d printer
  • Set to home axes
  • Verify the nozzle now rests above the print surface.

While seagas' design was in TinkerCad, I did my work in OnShape.
Document: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/ec0423a6c376a0781a7fc4ca/w/44887bf4da76bd7c85a66421/e/47b5f9d1b56aa351aabd4eb1

Printer:

MP Select Mini v2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes:

I recommend rotating the spacer to be printed on it's side to eliminate supports and obtain the best print quality. I also suggest a raft for stability, as the side of the spacer has a small footprint.

For reference, I printed mine in MatterHacker's purple PLA with 20% infill at .175mm layer height.

description.text:
Mod of FlexRail with Knobs on one and both Side.

I have the Idea to use my empty Filament spool for building another Track
for the ball track

Add a "Distance" Part so that enough height between two FlexFlexRail.
This Part is similar to ft 38246 "Bauplatte 15x15 1Z rot" but with 12x10mm
(and a Bad Knob 8-( )

Fischertechnik Steel Balls have a diameter of 12,7 mm.

The Knobs are longer so that no Support Structure is needed
but round knobs are better for slope of the Rail

Streched the Rail to 17mm (ft 15mm) wide outside
and 229,99 mm length (My maximum 8-( )

New Version 0.133 (10 Knobs on both side an it´s possible to glue extra Knob )

Add a minimum Angle Block (Halter) for connecting two FlexFlexRail
with a angle of 5° for the groove.
Angle Block with two cavitys for insert the FlexFlexRail when Angle Block is
fixed (e.g. inside a empty filament Spool)

(To do :Negative Angle Block for mounting on the Outside)
The Height of 58 mm came from the inside of the empty Filament Spool.

When I placed the Knobs on both end of the Rail I don´t realize that two Fischertechnik Blocks have a minimum disctance between the groove of 15 mm (MIddle to Middle).

Add two Version with knobs on the Outside too.
The distance from the outside knobs of two parts is 15 mm and you can use two
Fischertechnik Basic Blocks or the Double Basic Block

If you need a greater height you can strech the Block in the Slicer/Printer Software.
To Do : version with grooves on top and bottom

print_settings.Notes:: Printed this at 15% innfill and 0,1mm layers. No support needed. Took me almost 30 hours to print the bottom. The lid didn't take that long. The bottom could probably be printed at 0,2mm, but i'd keep the lid at 0,1. Not sure how it would affect the friction fit.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Please post images of your prints!
https://youtu.be/STPQBTL71DU

I wanted an easy way to carry my Hubsan drone in my backpack without it getting crushed or thrown around. I came up with this design wich holds it securly in place with the "feet holders" and a smal strip of foam glued to the lid.

It's so great to just put the drone in the lightweight box and throw it in the backpack or whatever, and not needing to worry about it. The case is very sturdy with 15% innfill!

At first the clearance of the lid lip and the box was a perfect friction fit, but after wear i now use a rubber band to keep the lid on. The lid has some small gaps in it to keep a rubber band in place.

I also fit a charging cable and extra propellers inside the box.

The box might fit other Hubsan drones if the distance between the "legs" are the same and the height is about the same.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,1

Infill:

15

Notes:

Printed this at 15% innfill and 0,1mm layers. No support needed. Took me almost 30 hours to print the bottom. The lid didn't take that long. The bottom could probably be printed at 0,2mm, but i'd keep the lid at 0,1. Not sure how it would affect the friction fit.

Add foam

I glued a small piece of cheap foam to the lid of the box. This keeps the drone from bouncing up and down during and hitting the lid during transport. Make sure the foam is thin / soft enought so that it doesn't push the lid off.

The other winter tires model is available as well.

A simple, small two piece case with 3mm hole mounting tabs for the little voltage meters you can find for variable power supplies. The model I have says DSN-DUM-368 on the the back. It is the one without the IC on the bottom, it has it tucked underneath the LED display. I am not sure if it will fit the models with the chips on the bottom but I will try it if I get any and see. I you try it and find out it works or not then let me know! There are (3) different cases. One with the gap for the wires on the right like the one pictured (that's the only one I have), one with the gap in the middle as I have seen online, and one without any gap in case your wires are somewhere else and you want to drill it out or have them run out the back.

Edit
The case does not quite fit the meters with the chip on the back of the PCB. I will try to do a version for those style chips when I get some in.

Edit 01/02/18
I added a case to fit a meter I got in with the circuit components on the back with center oriented wires. The mounting holes were smaller than the other meter I had as well. I unit I received was marked V20D-3P-11 on the back and hopefully it fits similar units.

comments.text: I have one with the chip on the bottom.  The voltmeter fits into the lid but the pcb overlaps the ledge a little. My pcb is 14.85mm  The tabs on the meter do not fit the bosses you provide.  Unrelated to the meter, the bottom with the center notch does not fit into the lid.  It is too big.  I dont think it is a printer issue on my side but not certain.
comments.author: wimberleytech

comments.text:
Hello,
Sorry to hear it didn't fit that particular chip. I am pretty certain the "standards" between manufacturers are fairly loose. I have some of the meters with the chip on the back on the way in the mail. I will adjust a case to fit them and post it when I do. Thank you for the heads up!
comments.author: wimberleytech

comments.text: Well...regardless...great contribution the maker world!!  BTW, I love these little meters.  I have some of the larger ones as well...attached to my analog supplies.

No bearings are in this part, it's solid.

author: Lim3rdGrade

description.text:
Generating electricity with the DC motor of an old gramophone and
a printed windmill. The first tests gives 2.5 V and lots
of vibrations of the windmill.
later more..

Print:
1 xBaseInOnePiece.stl
(or when the piece is too big
1x baseFront (for the front M4 bearing),
1x baseMid (for the back M4 bearing),
1x baseBackPart(for the generator and
M10 basebearing) 1x BaseBearingHolder.stl (to connect the base axis via the base bearing
to the base) 1x TailPart 3x windMillBlade
1x hub I added an extra plane to the windmillblade to get a
better print quality, after printing the extra plane can be removed with a saw. Put the stuff together with:
1 x DC motor gramophone 2 x threaded rod 500mm x M5
12 x nut M5
12 x ring M5 1 x threaded rod 200mm x M4
2 x bearing M4
4 x bolt M4 x 40
6 x nut M4
4 x ring M4 1 x threaded rod x M10
3 x nut M10
2 x ring M10
1 x bearing M10

title: Anet A6 Fan Mount and Cooling Duct

description.text:
I had problems of the various fan ducts falling off eventually.

I redesigned the "Anet A6 Air blower fixed Plate with cable Guide" by Wellenwerke and "Semi-circle nozzle fan for Anet A6" by HesselKoot.

The components can now be fastened together and held tight.

Fan Bracket-Cable Support-Fan Nozzle will need supports.

Supports not needed for the Semi-Circle Nozzle Fan

Semi-Circle Nozzle Fan has been completely redesigned with attaching points and a baffle on the inside. The baffle will help with air flow as the air transitions from the fan to the arms of the nozzle duct.

12/12/2017 Semi-Circle Nozzle Fan has been update. Now includes a small amount of material removed in fan interface to make sure fan blades do not hit it.

remixed_from.author: Nnivo
remixed_from.title: Heatbed Cable Holder for Anet A8 and others

description.text:
This is my version of the Cable Holder for the Anet A6.

This design uses only the rear 2 screws from the left rear bearing holder. It has a 3rd fastener location in the rear for a M4 fastener. The "H" plate will need to be drilled for this. Be careful that this fastener doesn't drag on the rear cross frame.

It incorporates recesses to locate tie wraps to secure the cables and harness. The recesses keep the tie wraps from moving and coming off.

The cable holding portion has been moved rearward from the A8 position to use a circular nozzle fan duct.

title: Tea Light Lantern - Remix for 35mm Tea Lights
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:498710 to modify the base to fit some tea lights I found in a box. Print the base and base cover from this thing, and print bobtato's very nice Lampglass per instructions on his thing page: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:498710.

I think the lamp glass looks better on this larger base when printed at 133% size. I include images of original size and 133% scaled.

Depending on your printer and plastic, you might need to up-size the base 1% or +/-. The fit is snug. Tiny bits of glue was only required to attach the lamp glass to the base cover. I used Proto Pasta Magnetic Iron which was a little too tight so the uploaded base is 1% larger.

Designed to fit ready made tea lights with auto on/off timers with a base diameter of 35.5mm. The base cover has a hole in the center to just fit around tea light wicks of 8.82mm.
